On 7/12/07, Eric J. Bowman <eric@...> wrote:
>
>  I don't believe every HTTP client in existence is broken.  Point any web
>  browser, on any platform, at a 410 response.  Now, hit "reload".  See?
>  The reload button is still available, and the client will indeed repeat
>  the request.  Every time.  4xx responses are not cacheable because they
>  do not indicate permanence.

Incorrect.

RFC 2616, section 13.4:
"A response received with a status code of 200, 203, 206, 300, 301 or
410 MAY be stored by a cache and used in reply to a subsequent
request, subject to the expiration mechanism, unless a cache-control
directive prohibits caching."

<http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec13.html#sec13.4>

-- 

Robert Sayre

"I would have written a shorter letter, but I did not have the time."
